Well actually speciation takes care of this. Species are allowed to 
exist =
until they stagnate for too long time. If some new structure 
appears throu=
gh mutations, the mutated individuals are separated in 
another species. Ea=
ch species is a local protected competition among 
individuals grouped by s=
imilarity. Consider it as a GA performed on 
near identical topologies. The=
n you can see NEAT as a algorithm 
running multiple GAs. So this is actuall=
y what you mean by dynamic 
programming.. or something. In fact this scheme=
 is far better than 
it. 
As for the idea of speculative structure, this is=
 the core of NEAT 
and it is actually Ken's idea :) 
Colin Green's idea is =
about phased searching, as far as I know. It is 
that after some structure =
is added through complexifying, a 
simplifying phase kicks in, removing any=
 unnecessary structure, thus 
returning the search down to a baseline low d=
imentional space while 
retaining the fitness (because of elitism). 

Peter=


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, c f <christofer_fransson@...> wrote:
>
> In =
dynamic programming the idea is to divide the
> solution in steps and then =
for each step present a
> fixed number of possible solutions.
> 
> Collin G=
reens idea is that speculative nodes are added
> to the solutions but it mi=
ght take time/generations
> before an added node are shown to be useful. 
>=
 
> Is it possible to apply dynamic programming approach
> to this area, to=
 evolve NEAT driven networks?
> 
> To combine local optimization and dynami=
c programming
> ideas?
> 
> Br,
> Christofer

> --- petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...>
> wrote:
> 
> > Given t=
he simplest topology (a perceptron
> > structure), the local 
> > minima is=
 just one. Perceptrons are always
> > guaranteed to converge on 
> > correc=
t weights. But increasing the dimentionality
> > of the solution 
> > incre=
ases the error surface's curvature as well. So
> > more dimentions 
> > mea=
ns more complex error surface. The coolest thing
> > in NEAT is that 
> > w=
hen it increases the dimentionality of the
> > solution, the individuals 
>=
 > are already located in a promising area of the new
> > space. In fact 
>=
 > those spaces are related to each other - you don't
> > know how the erro=
r 
> > surface is going to look like when you enter the new
> > space with =
more 
> > dimentions. There are unlimited possibilities. 
> > So what local=
 gradient search will do in essence is
> > pushing the 
> > weights towards=
 the *local* minumim.. It is not
> > guaranteed that this 
> > is the *solu=
tion*! It is simply because you don't
> > know the solution's 
> > dimentio=
nality at first. It may require 3 or
> > 21342532 dimentions. 
> > Don't fo=
rget that NEAT complexifies solutions
> > incrementaly. 
> > 
> > Peter

e local minimia

gy"

imia,

nism was

reed

> > > size

s "effective"

er does not make it

groups.com, "petar_chervenski"

e 
> > > genome

ersity, since most

 given topology can

 thus leaving out a

> > > > nearly 
> > > > > same in=
dividuals, i.e. clones.

ation, for example the

> > > > coding

ks in, when it focuses the search in the

 > of
